Name: Rivet Wars: Blitzkrieg Box
Description:
A collection of Rivet Wars components, including several hero figures and duplicates of core units from the Eastern Front.  It came in a plain carboard box that just said "blitzkkrieg box" rather than the more colorful windowed boxes of the true expansions.

8 heroes on stands
5 heroes as plugs
32 infantry
10 light vehicles
4 artillery
2 heavy vehicles
8 faction dice
patches & decals & comic-book-like mini-poster

Name: Coal & Guns!: Tactical level naval rules for the pre-dreadnought era
Description:
Coal & Guns! is a set of fast-play naval rules for the pre-dreadnaught era aiming to emphasize manoeuvre over detailed gunnery and damage tracking. Intended for squadrons of up to about half a dozen ships per side.

—user summary
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Kapprodd
Description:
A simple racegame with Canoes.You throw the dice and move as many steps as the dice shows. Sometimes you end your move at a spot where you either are lucky or poor.
In the beginning of the game you also have the opportunity to bet on whose canoe is going to win.

Name: Outback Crossing
Description:
Many animals are crisscrossing the Australian outback. To control where they're going in Outback Crossing, players lay down tiles one at a time onto a 5 x 5 grid (6 x 6 for five and six players), claim ownership of different "trails", and change things around with the action tiles. At the end of the game, single tiles won't score — except for the Tasmanian Devil — and the more tiles of one kind you have on a trail, the better the score; one per species on a trail also score very well. The Tasmanian Devil has a special value and scores even higher.

—description from the publisher

Name: Bazaar 1295
Description:
Story of the Game:

In the year 1295 (the year ending March 20, 1917), that is to say, 95 years after the time when Tehran was determined as capital of Iran, the small bazaar (market place) of Tehran which had not so much flourish before facing an increase in number of immigrants. Bazaar of Tehran was gradually becoming a big market place which needed a capable manager. For this reason a competition was held between 5 experienced businessmen of that time in order to decide who will become the “Elder” one of the bazaar.

Aim of the Game: By the end of the 5th day, the player with the highest total of gold coins wins the game.

How to play:

Stage 1: Taking the Tile of Goods
This stage has 2 parts. In the first part: each player randomly takes tiles from the bag keep some of them to expose to other pkayer and return the rest to the bag.

Stage 2: Transaction 
Any transaction is possible and free in this stage.
In this stage the players are permitted to transact and exchange any goods with the asset coins( gold coins ) or with other goods in only 2 minutes which should be controlled by a timer.

Stage 3: Costing and Sale (bidding)
In this stage ( considering the main board-game ) all the goods will be sold.each player holds one of the costing coins in his fists ( considering limitation of costing for each goods ) and keep his hand in front of the shop and all the players open their fists simultaneously. the person who has offered lower price takes action for selling his goods.

Stage 4: Storing
In this stage all the goods that have not been sold and remained in the shops will be flipped to the other side ( Black and white side) and will soon be expired. It means that , if they are not sold the next day,they will be removed feom the shop without receiving any amount of money and will be returned to the bag.

Stage 5: Movement of the day tracker token

End of the Game: 
The game will be finished on the 5th day after the end of the sale.

—description from the designer

Name: Small Number (ちいさいことはいいことだ )
Arc of Eckaris
Description:
Arc of Eckaris is a strategy board game for 4 to 6 players set in an original sci-fi universe.

During the game, you will use the influence of one of six unique factions to acquire planets, defeat your opponents, and/or capture the Arc of Eckaris.

Players take turns choosing from limited of number of actions to perform per turn including playing cards, using unique player powers, and deploying Influence, among others.

Players may win the game in one of three ways: Acquire 20 Victory Points, defeat all other players by depleting their Influence, or acquire the Arc of Eckaris.

—description from the publisher

Name: Scythe: Bonus Promo Pack – 6 Promo Encounter Cards numbers 37-42
Description:
Promo card 37 was available as part of The Dice Tower crowdfunding campaign.
Promo card 38 was available as part of the Watch It Played crowdfunding campaign.
Promo card 39 was available as part of the Game Boy Geek crowdfunding campaign.
Promo card 40 was available as part of the No Pun Included crowdfunding campaign.
Promo card 41 was available in Spielbox magazine.
Promo card 42 was available as part of The Secret Cabal crowdfunding campaign.

Name: Stratopoly
Description:
Yet another clone of Monopoly but with 144 cases, 24 series and many mechanics to influence your movement. Consequently, the game becomes a lot more strategic.

Main features:
All series are distributed at the beginning among the players
Players can use special cards to advance faster or slower, foward or backward.
Special cases or cards also allow players to move around the board strategically.

—description from the designer

Name: Multiverse War
Description:
In Multiverse War you are a Viceroy, chosen to lead one of the first expeditions trough the Stone Portal to colonize the new worlds. Explore the wilderness, push the Empire’s border by constructing new Fortresses. Hire mighty heroes, train powerful armies and defeat all enemies, old and new. Show that you are worthy of your Emperor’s trust, may he live forever.

Multiverse War is a blend of 4X, MOBA like heroes, area control block wargame. Key elements are RPG style character progression for heroes, armies gain battle experience and become stronger, unique heroes and different faction, modular map and random encounters. All these factors give high replayability.

A turn has 3 phases.
Revenue phase: Collect revenue from your starting settlement and expansions.
Build phase: Construct buildings or tile improvements, recruit armies or a hero
Action phase: Move all available units you wish to this turn

Win the game through conquest (conquering the opponent's starting settlement), domination (construct all 4 Fortresses), by constructing a new Stone Portal (by controlling stone mines on the map), trough magic (by reaching level 6 with your hero) or through might (reaching the highest rank with your 3 military units).

—description from the designer

Name: Discovery of Australia
Description: A roll-and-move game along a 100-space track depicting the various expeditions that discovered and settled Australia, from De Quiros and Torres in 1605, Tasman (1642), Dirk Hartog (1616), Dampier (1688 & 1699), Cook (1770), Phillp (1788), Bass (1798), Grant (1800) and Flinders 1802-03. Brief historical notes are given, and various spaces give penalties and bonuses.

Name: Ik hou van Gorinchem
Description: A promotionele game for the town of Gorinchem. It’s a retheme of The Game of Goose.

Name: Iron Magicians: The Search for the Magic Crystals
Description:
Iron Magicians is an interactive, pick-your-panel graphic novel for middle grade readers, full of adventure, magic, and fun!

In a steampunk version of nineteenth-century Paris, magical mana crystals have replaced steam and coal to power the machines and gadgets that make the city tick. On the eve of the Universal Exhibition of 1889, France seeks to demonstrate its power by unveiling a new secret weapon: the imposing Eiffel Tower, built with magic by Gustave Eiffel himself. But then disaster strikes--the mana crystals needed to power the tower are discovered missing!

You are a talented student in technomagy, the artful blend of magic and science. You are tasked with the mission of finding enough mana crystals to operate the tower. It's up to you to harness your intelligence, bravery, and skill to fulfill this secret mission.

—description from the publisher

Name: Blockers: The Stacking Game
Description:
A dexterity, deck-building tabletop experience brought to you by Crab Studios, from the mind of Niall Crabtree.

You have 90 seconds to build as many structures as possible, but be aware! At any moment other players can play cards against you. Will you fight back? Or will you save your cards and build a strong deck to come back harder next time around?

Cards difficult range from 1-7, though other modes will allow younger and more inexperienced players to still build in rapid fire succession by limiting the amount of higher level cards, this game is one for the whole family!

Miss the classic version of Blockers: The Stacking Game that hit Kickstarter back in March of 2019? Well don't worry, with competitive mode you can jump into the game without worrying about playing cards and building up your deck.

—description from the designer

Name: Birdtrails
Description:
Birdtrails is a pair of educational race games featuring 140 different kinds of North American birds.

In Game 1, placers roll and spin to make it back to the trailhead with the most impressive collection of birds seen.  Special points are awarded for taking time to improve the birds' habitat!

In Game 2, players do not use the spinner, and can only collect birds if they are able to correctly identify them, based on a photo.  Random events are reduced, making it more a game of skill and knowledge.

The game comes with 300 beautiful cards, featuring nature photography by Bob Ball.  A handful of scoring variants are also included.

Endorsed by the Greater Ozarks Audubon Society.

Name: Arkham Horror: The Card Game – Before the Black Throne: Mythos Pack
Description:
Before the Black Throne is the sixth and final Mythos Pack in "The Circle Undone" cycle for Arkham Horror: The Card Game.

After your battle to close the rips in reality in In the Clutches of Chaos, you have left your city and your world behind, traveling an impossible distance, and yet you are still many leagues from the nighted throne where your ultimate foe stirs. As you are chased by your fate across the cosmos, you may be forced to bring "empty space" into play, losing the top card of your deck as you place it facedown to embody the seemingly infinite space that divides you from the rest of humanity. This is not a location; it cannot be entered or investigated, and the only way to reclaim your lost card is to fill the empty space with a Cosmos location. These impossible places, drawn from the new Cosmos deck, do not have set places they must connect to. Rather, each Cosmos card has a connecting instruction you must obey in order to place it. Torn from all you know, it may be easy to surrender to the existential dread, but even if all you can do is delay the inevitable, the battle is not over yet!

—description from the publisher
Families: Collectible: Living Card Game (Fantasy Flight Games)
Game: Arkham Horror – The Card Game
Game: Arkham Horror TCG – The Circle Undone
Series: Arkham Horror Files (Fantasy Flight Games)

Name: Quatro
Description:
A cross between Scrabble and Memory/Concentration/Pelmanism. 
—user summary

Quatro is a word game for 2, 3 or 4 players. Words are formed by remembering the position of letter coins placed face down on the playing board. Players compete for the highest score by making words of at least four letters. Keen memory and ingenuity are rewarded by bonus points for Premium and Dividend words.

OBJECTIVE

The objective is to turn up coins all of which together form a word of four or more letters. Scoring is based on the value of the letters in the word. In addition, bonuses are scored for Premium words, which are words containing five or more letters, and also for Dividend words, which are words made entirely of letters all of the same color (all gold or all black).

Charts, showing the frequency of the letters and the point value assigned to each letter, are printed on the playing board.

—description from the rulebook

Name: Zoo-phonics 3 in 1 Game
Description:
This early product of Zoo-phonics uses different decks with sets of pairs of cards. One deck has 26 pairs for each letter of the alphabet, along with the name of the animal assigned to that letter, e.g. Allie Alligator, Honey Horse, Vincent Vampire Bat. Another deck has 40 pairs of 2- or 3-letter blends and digraphs.

The three games are adaptations of traditional childrens' games: Zoophonia (Old Maid, except the one with the Zoophonia card wins); Zoo-Fish (Go Fish), and Zoo-Memory (Memory).  The alphabet deck also says it can be used for spelling games.  Whenever cards are requested or matches made, the player must say the card's animal name, make its sound, and do its sign according to the Zoo-phonics kinesthetic system.

—user summary

Name: Time Thief
Description:
There are only two time-travel devices in existence, and you and your friend have managed to steal them. They will allow you to be the perfect thieves, traveling through time to when your target is most vulnerable and snatching it away to the future ... er, present.

It wouldn't have been possible without your friend, but now that you have the time-travel device, you don't need him. So you have decided to go back to the night the time-travel devices were invented and steal them BOTH. Unfortunately, your backstabbing buddy had the same idea.

GOAL

You need to infiltrate the facility with the time-travel devices while the cameras are off, the alarm is disabled, and the robot guard is deactivated. If neither player successfully infiltrates, or both players infiltrate at the same time, shuffle the decks and start a new game. After all, you can both travel through time, so you might as well try again.

—description from the box and the rulebook

Name: Castlecomb
Description:
Castlecomb is a card laying game of territory control for 1-5 players.  As you play cards of terrain, settlements, and strongholds to create territories of your own, watch out as other players are looking to do the same.  The cards a have requirements that have to be met to be played and to be operational to score at the end of the game, where the high score is the victor.

—description form the designer

Name: SPPOKER
Description:
"A unique card game of Spelling and Poker."

The Deck: The cards have traditional playing cards suit and rank in one corner (e.g. two of clubs, queen of hearts), and a letter of the alphabet in the opposite corner.  There are also 2 jokers.

Play: For a hand, each player is dealt 7 cards, and looks for both the best poker hand, and the longest word, they have in their hand. Then each player holds out a fist with 0-2 tokens in it, and all open their hands at the same time.  0 tokens means they are trying for the best poker hand, 1 token for the longest word, 2 tokens for both (Double Down).

Scoring: For those trying for just the best poker hand, or just the longest word, the player who has the best hand gets 1 point, with tied players each getting 1 point.  A player going Double Down must have the best hand in both areas, with no ties. If they do, they get 4 points, if not, they lose 2 points.

More hands are played until one player has 12 points in a 2-player game, 10 points for 3 or 4, 8 points for 5 or 6, 6 points for 7 or 8.

—user summary

Name: Kern Alphabet Card Games
Description:
This deck has two copies of each letter of the alphabet, with the letters painted by Donna Kern in delightful and creative ways. For example, the 'A' is an A-shaped apple with a bit out of it; the 'K' is made from keys, the 'R' from a ribbon, etc.

Rules are included for several games: Kern Rummy (draw and discard until you can use all your hand to make one or more words); children's games Go Fish, Rotten Egg (Old Maid) and Concentration; and KernWords (laying down cards in crossword fashion, with new cards not having to make words in every direction).

—user summary

Name: Adrift: Lost at Sea
Description:
Adrift: Lost at Sea is a 2 - 4 player co-operative ocean survival game. The players, the stranded crew in a life raft, work together to survive until the event deck runs out. Each event brings challenges such as storms, rotting food, or heat stroke.

Each turn, players choose actions such as fishing, repairing the boat, navigating, nursing each other back to health, or curing ailments. Each action has a cost in fish, and must also be balanced with other players' actions or cause additional structural damage to the flimsy vessel. Meanwhile, precious drinking water is constantly running out, and can only be replenished through a fortunate turn in the weather.

If your crew survives the harrowing journey, you can sing a sea shanty of your exploits, by compiling the verses written on the bottom of each event card.

Description from the publisher:

Adrift: Lost at Sea is a challenging, 2 - 4 player, cooperative card game that focuses on bringing people together. It’s like the Oregon Trail meets a 16th Century shipwreck - As you make the journey back home on the unforgiving tides, your table becomes the lifeboat and you become the survivors. Plus, at the end of the game, you'll get a unique sea shanty about your voyage to sing (or chant) together and reminisce about your adventure!

On this journey home, you'll endure storms, navigate the seas, balance and repair your tiny lifeboat, fish for sustenance, and work together to help each other survive!

Players try to complete all cards in the route home deck while outlasting storms and maladies to win the game.

Name: Pla-Pak
Description:
The Pla-Pak deck has two cards for each letter, showing a few items that start with that letter, and two "Dunce" cards, showing a boy on a stool wearing a traditional Dunce cap.

Rules for 4 games are included:


     Rummy-Dunce: 2-4 players each get 10 cards. Typical draw-and-discard play is done until one player can use his hand to spell one or more words; they score 10 points plus 1 point per each letter in others' hands that are not used in words they spell from their hands. Dunce cards are wild and stand for any letter. The first to 50 points wins. 



     Grand Champion: Like Rummy-Dunce, except the discard pile is spread out to see each card. One can take any card in the discard pile along with every card above it as long as they immediately lay down a word using that letter; only one card is discarded. When the deck is used up players use as many of their cards as they can to form words, and get one point per unused card. Each player is eliminated on reaching 50 total points, and the last player left is Grand Champion. 



     Hit the Bowl: A player sits in a chair and throws each card one at a time at a bowl 6 feet away. After the deck is all used the player gets 1 point for each card in the bowl, and spells as many words as they can from those cards, scoring the length of each word. First player to 50 wins. 



     Dunce: Played like Old Maid, using just one of the Dunce cards. 


—user summary

Name: Star Trek (The Original Series) Spock's Logic Puzzle Box
Description:
Voyage boldly into the strange new worlds of Star Trek and the incredible adventures of the U.S.S. Enterprise by pitting your wits against this collection of puzzles inspired by the brilliant and ever-logical Mr. Spock.

'Star Trek: Spock's Logic Puzzle Box can be played alone, with friends or as a team competition. Two to six players work best.

—description from the publisher

Name: Combilet
Description:
Combilet is a combination letter game consisting of 76 cards. Each card has four selections of single and two letter combinations. The red side is made up of consonant-vowel, and vowel-consonant combinations, such as SA-AS, and the black side is made up of either two single letters, or a single letter and a double consonant, such as PR, TH etc., with some exceptions.

"The selections on each card are listed on the upper left hand corner. [Note there are four upper-left corners depending on how you orient the card, each one having a different selection in large font.]
—description from the rulebook

There are rules for 3 games:

Combilet

Each player has a 5-card hand. On their turn a player may do one of these:

     Play a word of 5+ letters from the hand in front them. 
     Play a word of 3 or 4 letters from the hand to a common pool. 
     Take a word from the pool by adding cards that make it a 5+ letter word. 
     Take a word from another player by using cards that increase it, change it, or replace single letters with 2-letter combinations. 


Then they fill their hand back out to 5 cards. Play presumably goes until the deck runs out or some other end condition is reached.

Each word's score encourages using 2-letter combinations: its score is 5 points each for the first two combinations, 10 points each for each combination beyond two, and 1 point for each single-letter card in the word.

Fast Combilet

Each player gets 5 cards which they try to make one or more words out of.  Scoring is similar to that in regular Combilet. The player with the highest-scoring hand gets his score and that of each other play.

Solitaire

The deck is split into 5 piles, and the player makes words from the top cards, laying them aside and trying to finish the whole deck.

—user summary

Name: Words
Description:
From a deck of 48 letter cards, the dealer chooses the size of the hand for the deal, dealing 3, 4 or 5 cards to each player face down. At a signal from the dealer, everyone looks at their hand and tries to make a word using all their cards.  They can discard cards and be dealt replacements as desired. The first person to make a word says "Word!" and gets 10 points; achieving 100 points total over several hands wins the game.

An alternate way to play is to deal 8 cards per player. Players take turns placing one letter in the center of the table; if a player completes a word using all letters they take them and start a new "trick". Taking the most words wins.

—user summary

Name: Simple Wargame
Description:
This game dates back to the Persians, who played a crude version in which the board was thirteen feet across. The counter was made of stone and took forty slaves to lift; as a result, play was slow. Modern gamers have speeded play, but have not modified the basic futility of the system.

First published in The Space Gamer (Issue 62 - Apr 1983), under Famous Game Designers' School.

Name: Ultracombat Normandy
Description:
Ultracombat: Normandy is an easy, fast-paced set of squad-level skirmish wargames rules for depicting the frenetic close-ranged combat that occurred during the Normandy Campaign of WW2. The system puts players in command of up to a platoon of infantry supported with tanks, AT guns and devastating heavy weapons.

Key Features:

     Forces are built in elements, so players can play the real tactics of the day like scouting, suppressive fire, and fire and movement.
     Command is an integral part of the game.
     Real ranges of weapons are used so measuring on the battlefield is kept to a minimum.
     A unique card-based system gives players tactical options in play.


—description from the publisher

Name: Hemlock
Description:
Hemlock is a strategic, medieval themed, card game.

In it, your goal is to manipulate an unfolding conspiracy to your advantage. Populate your King's court with high-valued figures, reduce the likelihood of their deaths, and minimize your opponents’ ability to do the same.

Hemlock features a play deck of 66 cards (11 cards per suit). Each card has a static or variable point value as well as an associated ability. When a player plays a card from their hand, they choose to play it for either points or for ability.

Hemlock is played over a series of rounds. At the beginning of each round, 2 cards are dealt face down to the center of the play area. These are the conspiracy cards. Actions played during the course of a round can change the conspiracy cards, but there are always, and only, 2 conspiracy cards in a given round.

Players take turns moving clockwise, playing 1 card per turn from their hand with the goal of accruing the highest round-point total. The player with most points at the end of a round earns the privilege of examining the 2 conspiracy cards and then assigning them to 2 different players' courts (score piles).

The number of cards in each player's court is known to all, but the value of the cards are kept secret even to their owner until a specified number of cards is present in a given court. When this number of cards is reached, the game ends. Players tally the value of the cards in their court (the ones that aren't poisoned by Hemlock!) and the player with the highest valued court wins.

—description from the publisher

Name: Ravehard: Magiczna Gra Karciana
Description:
Something's rotten in the realm of Labamba...

The annual rave party is an event where every self-respecting wizard and sorceress has to make an appearance; however, this year's party was so epic, that in the morning the guests – all tired and hungover – discovered that someone has murdered the Archmage!
No one knows how, no one knows when. It's quite possible that even the murderer him or herself is not aware of what happened last night, since barely anyone remembers anything. Unfortunately, according to the ancient laws of Labamba, the one that kills the Archmage may become a powerful Darchmage, bringing Darkness onto the land. And if there is one thing that Darkness hates, it's fun, techno, lasers and glitter – which is all that is dear to the magical folk.
Thus, it's time to pull yourselves together, put your holo detective hats on your aching heads and catch the killer, before he grows too powerful!

RAVEHARD: Magiczna Gra Karciana is a party game that mixes elements of classic card battle games, games of deduction and deception, as well as more cooperative titles. It's meant to be played by 2-5 players aged 12 and more.

Over the course of the game, which lasts three rounds, the players will have to work together in order to discover who killed the Archmage during the magical rave party yesternight. To achieve this goal, they'll have to overcome dangerous obstacles, including boss fights (each boss capable of summoning powerful minions) and unpredictable events. After each round the players gain a new clue which sheds some light on the last night's incident and points towards a possible murder weapon.
If the players manage to survive all three rounds, they reach the Archmage's Chamber. There they may incapacitate one of them, should they be certain that he's the killer. If they are correct – they win the game; if they are wrong – the murderer steps out of the shadows and attacks the rest of the players. The side that emerges victorious from this final confrontation wins the game.

Do not trust anyone – not even yourself! Each player starts the game with two different objects which may turn out to be the murder weapons – or they may prove your innocence. During your turn you may switch the objects with those belonging to other players in order to frame them and clear your name. However, not until the very end will it be possible to tell which object is really the murder weapon. Thus, during the game you'll have to bluff, form alliances, deceive and distract, both openly – and secretly, using the Flirt Cards that let you pass private messages, scheme and conspire (and flirt).

This game is for you if you enjoy playing such titles as Magic: The Gathering, Munchkin, Hero Realms, Epic Spell Wars of the Battle Wizards, Love Letter, Mascarade, Coup, Not Alone, PENNY DREADFUN: Duchy, Demony, Dickensy.

—description from the publisher
